integrations_researched.name: ib_async
integrations_researched.description: Python sync/async framework for Interactive Brokers API - successor to ib_insync

imports: from ib_async import IB, Stock, Future, Forex, Contract
from ib_async import MarketOrder, LimitOrder, StopOrder, StopLimitOrder
api_patterns.market_depth_example:
ticker = ib.reqMktDepth(contract)
bids = ticker.domBids
asks = ticker.domAsks

infrastructure.tws_or_gateway_running: Must have IB TWS or Gateway running with API enabled

gotchas: ibapi package from IB is NOT needed - ib_async implements full IBKR API protocol internally
Each connection requires unique clientId
Free delayed data uses reqMarketDataType(3) or (4); real-time requires paid subscriptions
Market data lines limited to 100 per username
Level 2 market depth requires specific subscriptions
Futures historical data limited to 2 years
Bar sizes 30 seconds and lower limited to 6 months of history
Continuous futures (CONTFUT) only for historical data, not real-time or orders
Need $500 USD in account plus cost of market data subscriptions for live data
ib_insync creator (Ewald de Wit) passed away in early 2024 - ib_async is the maintained successor

integrations_researched.name: Dash
integrations_researched.description: Python framework for building ML & data science web apps with real-time visualization

imports: from dash import Dash, html, dcc, callback, Input, Output, State
api_patterns.real_time_pattern: dcc.Interval(id='interval-component', interval=1000, n_intervals=0) with callback to update graph

gotchas: For high-frequency real-time updates, consider WebSocket integration instead of Interval polling
Large datasets may cause browser performance issues - use downsampling
Debug mode should be disabled in production
Consider using dash-bootstrap-components for better UI

integrations_researched.name: River
integrations_researched.description: Online machine learning library for streaming data with incremental learning

imports: from river import compose, linear_model, metrics, preprocessing
from river import tree, ensemble, drift, anomaly
from river import time_series, cluster, stats
api_patterns.initialization:
model = compose.Pipeline(
    preprocessing.StandardScaler(),
    linear_model.LogisticRegression()
)
metric = metrics.Accuracy()
api_patterns.online_learning_pattern:
for x, y in stream:
    y_pred = model.predict_one(x)
    metric.update(y, y_pred)
    model.learn_one(x, y)

gotchas: Uses learn_one() NOT fit_one() (different from older creme library)
Data passed as Python dict (not numpy arrays/DataFrames) for single instances
Order of magnitude faster than PyTorch/TensorFlow/sklearn for single-instance learning
Drift detection crucial for trading - markets exhibit concept drift
Models don't need retraining - they adapt continuously
For deep learning, use deep-river extension (combines with PyTorch)

integrations_researched.name: pandas_market_calendars
integrations_researched.description: Exchange trading calendars for market hours, holidays, and early closes
gotchas: 50+ exchange calendars supported
Provides market open/close times with timezone support
Handles intraday breaks (e.g., Asian market lunch breaks)
Holiday and early close calendars included

integrations_researched.name: exchange_calendars
integrations_researched.description: Alternative exchange calendar library with trading schedules and sessions
gotchas: Uses ISO MIC codes (XCME vs CME)
Formerly trading_calendars from Quantopian
50+ global exchanges supported
Provides session open/close times and breaks

integrations_researched.name: NumPy
integrations_researched.description: Fundamental package for numerical computing in Python

api_patterns.verified_against: Common knowledge - core Python scientific stack

gotchas: Use appropriate dtypes (float32 vs float64) for memory efficiency
Vectorized operations crucial for performance
Consider numba for JIT compilation of hot paths

integrations_researched.name: Pandas
integrations_researched.description: Data analysis and manipulation library with DataFrame structures

api_patterns.verified_against: Common knowledge - core Python data science stack

gotchas: Use category dtype for repeated strings to save memory
Rolling windows for streaming calculations
Consider Polars for extreme performance needs

integrations_researched.name: asyncio
integrations_researched.description: Python's built-in async I/O library for concurrent programming
gotchas: Single thread, single process model with event loop
Best for I/O-bound workloads with high concurrency
Thousands of coroutines can run in one thread
ib_async is built on asyncio - they integrate seamlessly
Use async context managers for cleanup

integrations_researched.name: Interactive Brokers Market Data
integrations_researched.description: IB's market data service requirements for Level 1 and Level 2 data

api_patterns.smart_routing_depth: Available in API v974+ for aggregated depth from all exchanges

requirements: Market data subscriptions for each exchange
$500 USD minimum in account plus subscription costs
100 market data lines limit per username

gotchas: Level 2 market depth data sent without sampling but not guaranteed complete
Odd lot orders not included in market depth
reqMarketDataType(3) or (4) for delayed data without subscription
Smart-routing market depth requires API v974+ and TWS v974+
CME futures require CME Real-time subscription for live data

integrations_researched.name: CME Trading Calendar
integrations_researched.description: CME Group trading hours and holiday schedules for futures markets

api_patterns.api_description: CME Reference Data API provides trading schedules including 1 year historical and 1 year forward-looking

trading_hours.typical_equity_futures: Sunday 5:00 PM CT to Friday 4:00 PM CT
trading_hours.early_close_days: Usually 1:00 PM CT for equity products

gotchas: Trading hours vary by product - always verify per contract
Holiday schedules published ~2 weeks in advance
Early close days have reduced trading hours
Use pandas_market_calendars or exchange_calendars for programmatic access

unverified_claims.claim: Mac Ultra can utilize 80% of resources for rapid strategy discovery
unverified_claims.reason: Hardware-specific optimization is feasible but actual utilization depends on implementation - Python GIL limits CPU parallelism for pure Python code
unverified_claims.mitigation: Use multiprocessing for CPU-bound tasks, asyncio for I/O-bound tasks, and consider NumPy/Numba for vectorized operations

unverified_claims.claim: Demo account supports unlimited aggressive experimentation
unverified_claims.reason: IB demo accounts have limitations - may have simulated fills, delayed data, and different behavior than live accounts
unverified_claims.mitigation: Test critical functionality, be aware demo may not perfectly replicate live trading conditions

recommendations.recommendation: Use ib_async over ibapi or ib_insync
recommendations.reason: ib_async is the actively maintained successor to ib_insync, implements full IBKR protocol internally (no ibapi dependency), and has modern async support

recommendations.recommendation: Use River for online/incremental machine learning
recommendations.reason: River is specifically designed for streaming data, supports concept drift detection (critical for financial markets), and is much faster than batch ML for single-instance learning

recommendations.recommendation: Use Dash with WebSocket integration for real-time dashboard
recommendations.reason: Dash's Interval component works for moderate update frequencies, but WebSocket integration is better for high-frequency trading data visualization

recommendations.recommendation: Use pandas_market_calendars for exchange calendar management
recommendations.reason: Actively maintained, supports CME and other futures exchanges, provides holiday schedules and early closes

recommendations.recommendation: Ensure IB market data subscriptions are active before going live
recommendations.reason: Level 1 and Level 2 data require paid subscriptions; without them, only delayed data is available

recommendations.recommendation: Implement concept drift detection with River's drift module
recommendations.reason: Financial markets exhibit concept drift - strategies that work in one regime may fail in another. ADWIN, PageHinkley, DDM are available

recommendations.recommendation: Use asyncio throughout the application architecture
recommendations.reason: ib_async is built on asyncio - consistent async patterns will provide better performance and cleaner code

recommendations.recommendation: Consider multiprocessing for CPU-intensive ML operations
recommendations.reason: Python GIL limits true CPU parallelism in threads - use multiprocessing for parallel model training/prediction
